ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course expanded my knowledge in Arabic grammar and culture. I believe that I gained better listening and reading skills after taking this course.
Knowledge of the grammar, vocabulary and patterns in the Arabic Language (MSA) but also some knowledge of the spoken variety (Shami).
breadth of Arabic vocabulary, stronger concepts in Arabic grammar in order to create more complex sentences
I learned how to really problem solve, this is a challenging course with a lot of required persistence

I gained insights about a culture different than my own - the most valuable knowledge a Yalie has the opportunity to gain. I also learned how to read and write in a language that is close to my heart.
I think my listening comprehension skills improved the most because of the transcription exercises we had to do for each chapter
I learned a lot of basic Arabic grammar and vocabulary

I gained an immense amount of diversified Arabic grammar structures as well as vocabulary and culture. I additionally learned how to properly conjugate in the past and present tense as well as recognize different case endings. I struggled with speaking and pronouncing the language during my first semester of the language, but was greatly impacted and aided by the TA and professor Aziz in correcting my speech abilities.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that the lessons on grammar could be better organized such as having a deck of slides prepared before class and better communication on when assignments are due, but overall I enjoyed the class and the collaborative environment.

I would have liked to actively talk more in class. Towards the end of the semester we began to do more in-class discussion but in the first half it was mainly listening so I was less confident in speaking.

In general I thought it was a very good course in that it was enjoyable and effective for teaching Arabic. I think  its main strength is that it moves quickly and introduces a very large amount of vocabulary (I think it is a large amount, it feels large in the moment). This is also it weakness towards the end in order to finish the units we moved very quickly and so it was hard to learn at such a pace emphasis on vocabulary is also tricky.  I did wish we had practiced speaking in class a bit more.
Useful textbook
It moves slightly too fast

The strengths of the course far exceed the weaknesses. The core strengths are the following:

- Active learning environment 
- Engaged and available professor
- Accommodates multiple learning styles 
- Multiple opportunities provided to excel outside of the classroom 
- Respect between professor and student

strengths: balanced distribution of assignments for grammar, reading, listening, and speaking
weaknesses: unclear communication of expectations for larger assignments like the final project
I think this course could practice speaking a little bit more but I think it is otherwise a great course

Strengths:
Online homework
1-on-1 office hours or access to professor/TA
Clarifications presented at beginning of classes
Cultural immersion via only Arabic language drills or lots of music 
Various tools and methods for learning (Lingco, Kahoot, textbook, etc)

Weaknesses:
The course moves particularly fast for those who have had zero previous engagement with the language or culture.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend taking this class if you are interested in learning the Arabic language but it is a lot of work as an L2 language.

Yes, I would recommend it very strongly, every student should learn Arabic. Also it is always an enjoyable part of the day which I think many students would benefit from considering that our lives have many stressful classes.
If they are interested in learning Arabic, yes

I would recommend this course to students who seek a challenge in learning a new language. Though Arabic is definitely difficult compared to other languages, there is no reason why a student would be ill-advised to take this course. I loved everything about it and I am sure someone else would as well.
If they want to learn Arabic yes!

I would very much recommend this course to other students. I would do so if said students were willing to step into a challenging zone and out of their comfort zone in terms of academic rigger. As well as, if students would be willing to focus and facilitate their growth since they will have phenomenal instruction from a wise professor.
